DataElement.preferredName: Disease or Disorder Ovarian Carcinoma Histology Classification Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the ovarian carcinoma histology classification.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function._The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.

Concepts.definition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Property.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Concepts.definition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm originating from the surface ovarian epithelium.  It accounts for the greatest number of deaths from malignancies of the female genital tract and is the fifth leading cause of cancer fatalities in women.  It is predominantly a disease of older white women of northern European extraction, but it is seen in all ages and ethnic groups.  Adenocarcinomas constitute the vast majority of ovarian carcinomas.  The pattern of metastatic spread in ovarian carcinoma is similar regardless of the microscopic type.  The most common sites of involvement are the contralateral ovary, peritoneal cavity, para-aortic and pelvic lymph nodes, and liver.  Lung and pleura are the most common sites of extra-abdominal spread.  The primary form of therapy is surgical.  The overall prognosis of ovarian carcinoma remains poor, a direct result of its rapid growth rate and the lack of early symptoms. --2002_The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains._A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mixed adenocarcinoma and squamous cell or epidermoid carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: An invasive carcinoma composed of malignant glandular cells and malignant squamous cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A cell with empty-appearing cytoplasm when viewed with a light microscope.

Concepts.definition: A cell with empty-appearing cytoplasm when viewed with a light microscope.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence in a sample of tissue that resembles endometrial tissue.

Concepts.definition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence in a sample of tissue that resembles endometrial tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A reproductive cell of the body. Germ cells are egg cells in females and sperm cells in males.

Concepts.definition: Gametes, also known as sex cells or germ cells, are the cells that come together during fertilization or conception in organisms that reproduce sexually.  Their genetic complement consists of a single set of unpaired chromosomes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A slow-growing, malignant tumor, characterize by the presence of granulosa-like cells and Call-Exner bodies, that is almost always found in the ovary. In rare cases, it has also been found in the testicle.  There are two types of granulosa cell tumor that can be distinguished under the microscope: the adult and the juvenile.  The testicular juvenile granulosa cell tumors are perhaps the most common congenital testicular neoplasms.

Concepts.definition: A slow-growing sex cord-stromal tumor characterized by the presence of granulosa-like cells and Call-Exner bodies. It is almost always found in the ovary and rarely in the testis. There are two types of granulosa cell tumors: the adult and the juvenile.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A group of tumors affecting the female reproductive system, characterized by the presence of epithelial and stromal elements. It includes the following clinicopathological entities: adenofibroma, adenomyoma, Mullerian adenosarcoma, and malignant mixed mesodermal (Mullerian) tumor.

Concepts.definition: A group of tumors affecting the female reproductive system, characterized by the presence of epithelial and stromal elements. It includes the following clinicopathological entities: adenofibroma, adenomyoma, Mullerian adenosarcoma, and malignant mixed mesodermal (Mullerian) tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: of or relating to or resembling papilla.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to or resembling papilla.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of or producing or containing serum.

Concepts.definition: Of or producing or containing serum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

It accounts for the greatest number of deaths from malignancies of the female genital tract and is the fifth leading cause of cancer fatalities in women.  It is predominantly a disease of older white women of northern European extraction, but it is seen in all ages and ethnic groups.  Adenocarcinomas constitute the vast majority of ovarian carcinomas. Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm originating from the surface ovarian epithelium.  It accounts for the greatest number of deaths from malignancies of the female genital tract and is the fifth leading cause of cancer fatalities in women.  It is predominantly a disease of older white women of northern European extraction, but it is seen in all ages and ethnic groups.  Adenocarcinomas constitute the vast majority of ovarian carcinomas.  The pattern of metastatic spread in ovarian carcinoma is similar regardless of the microscopic type.  The most common sites of involvement are the contralateral ovary, peritoneal cavity, para-aortic and pelvic lymph nodes, and liver.  Lung and pleura are the most common sites of extra-abdominal spread.  The primary form of therapy is surgical.  The overall prognosis of ovarian carcinoma remains poor, a direct result of its rapid growth rate and the lack of early symptoms.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
